fields.name: Advertising & Marketing
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Advertising & Marketing are Customer Privacy; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion.

RiskHorizon would also then point to energy management from an environmental; and customer welfare from a social; and business ethics and data privacy from a governance perspective. From a environmental perspective, particularly for larger firms, energy use and therefore Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions can be of concern. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving).

Contamination Risk: Advertising & Marketing operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description:
The Advertising & Marketing industry is comprised of companies that create advertising campaigns for use in media, display, or direct mail advertising and related services including market research. Advertising and marketing companies are engaged primarily by businesses selling consumer products, entertainment, financial services, technology products, and telecommunication services. Larger advertising companies are structured as holding companies, owning multiple agencies across the globe that provide a wide range of services such as custom publishing, brand consultancy, mobile and online 
marketing, and public relations. For any advertising campaign, the same company may be engaged in all aspects, from graphic arts and content creation to data analytics, marketing research, and media planning and buying, or the company may be in charge only of certain aspects.

fields.name: Aerospace and Defense
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Aerospace & Defence are Energy Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Data Security; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, pollution, climate change and sustainable sourcing from an environmental; and child labour, transparency, health & safety and working conditions from a social; and bribery and corruption from a governance perspective. GHG emissions and pollution pose as significant environmental impacts during production and transport. Consideration of current and historical use of radioactive materials will also be significant. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding) in location, distribution network and supply chain. There is a sourcing risk, particularly the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and potential forced/ child labour. Working conditions, fair pay and health checks/screening are all areas of consideration, as well as health & safety. Consideration of anti-bribery and corruption around contracts and fair pricing are also significant.

Contamination Risk: Aerospace & Defence operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in the Aerospace & Defense industry include manufacturers of commercial aircraft, aircraft parts, aerospace and defense products, as well as defense prime contractors. Commercial aircraft manufacturers represent approximately one quarter of industry revenues and sell mainly to commercial airlines and governments. Aerospace and defense parts manufacturers represent the largest segment of the industry by total revenue, selling primarily to governments. Both aerospace and defense manufacturers operate globally and serve a global customer base. Defense primes represent  approximately one quarter of total industry revenues and manufacture products including military aircraft, space vehicles, missile systems, ammunition, small arms, naval ships, and other commercial and military vehicles. Their customers consist of various government agencies and related businesses with global operations. The defense prime category also includes firearms manufacturers that sell to law enforcement agencies, businesses, distributors, retailers, and consumers. Key sustainability topics within the industry include the energy efficiency and emissions profile of products and management of manufacturing energy and waste.

fields.name: Agricultural Products
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Agricultural Products are GHG Emissions; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Product Quality & Safety; Employee Health & Safety; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the application of Genetic Modification (GM) and chemicals, climate change, land rights, biodiversity and waste from an environmental; and fair contracts and workers rights from a social perspective. Considerations with respect to GM and chemical use are focused around biodiversity impacts, soil degradation and water pollution, especially the use of pesticides and excessive fertilizers. Biodiversity impacts are also important in the context of loss of virgin forest and deforestation including for cash crops such as soya and palm oil. Climate change impacts include impacts to crop growth, yield, water demand and availability and flooding. Also, illegal conversion of land for agricultural purposes should be considered. Fair contract conditions and payment of suppliers is an important consideration, as well as workers rights and in particular the risk of enforced/ child labour. 

Contamination Risk: Agricultural Products operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Agricultural Products industry is engaged in processing, trading, and distributing vegetables and fruits, and producing and milling agricultural commodities such as grains, sugar, consumable oils, maize, soybeans, and animal feed. Agricultural products are sold directly to consumers and businesses for use in consumer and industrial products. Companies in the industry typically purchase agricultural products from entities that grow such products (either directly or indirectly) to then conduct value-adding activities (e.g., processing, trading, distributing, and milling). Agricultural products companies are also involved in wholesale and distribution. Companies in the industry may source a substantial portion of agricultural commodities from third-party growers in various countries. Therefore, managing sustainability risks within the supply chain is critical to securing a reliable supply of raw materials and reducing the risk of price increases and volatility over the long term.

fields.name: Air Freight & Logistics
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Air Freight & Logistics are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Supply Chain Management; Critical Incident Risk Management. 

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management and hazardous materials from an environmental, and systemic risk and cyber security from a governance perspective. Hazardous materials, particularly risks of spills from fuel use are a key consideration and the general use of packaging materials should also be considered. The industry is particularly vulnerable to systemic risk such as air traffic control failure and cyber attacks. From a governance perspective, issues associated with bribery and corruption should also be considered.

Contamination Risk: Air Freight & Logistics operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Air freight and logistics companies provide freight services and transportation logistics to both businesses and individuals. There are three main industry segments: air freight transportation, post and courier services, and transportation logistics services. Companies in the industry earn revenue from one or more of the segments and range from non-asset-based to asset-heavy. Transportation logistics services include contracting with road, rail, marine, and air freight companies to select and hire appropriate transportation. Services can also include customs brokerage, distribution management, vendor consolidation, cargo insurance, purchase-order management, and customised logistics information. The industry is key to global trade, granting it a degree of demand stability.

fields.name: Airlines
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Airlines are GHG Emissions; Labour Practices; Competitive Behaviour; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management, air quality and hazardous materials from an environmental, and transition risk (consumer preferences in the context of climate change) and systemic risk from a governance perspective. Hazardous materials, particularly risks of spills from fuel use are a key consideration. The industry is particularly vulnerable to systemic risk such as air traffic control failure and cyber attacks. From a social perspective, the working conditions and contractual arrangements of staff and related labour relations issues should be considered.

Contamination Risk: Airlines operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Airlines industry is comprised of companies that provide air transportation globally to passengers for both leisure and business purposes. This includes commercial full-service, low-cost, and regional airlines. Full-service carriers typically use a hub-and-spoke model to design their routes within countries and internationally. Low-cost carriers usually offer a smaller number of routes as well as no-frills service to their customers. Regional carriers typically operate under contract to full-servicecarriers, expanding the network of the larger carriers. Many airline companies also have a cargo segment in their operations from which they generate additional revenue. It is common within the industry for companies to form partnerships or join alliances in order to increase network size. Operating as an alliance allows airlines to offer customers access to international or otherwise underserved itineraries on multiple airlines under one ticket. At the same time, airlines share some overhead costs and increase their competitive position in the global market without having to operate outside their home country.

fields.name: Airports and related services
fields.description:
Airports and Related Services is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to fuel management, air quality, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, hazardous materials from an environmental; and transition risk and systemic risk from a governance perspective. Hazardous materials is important to consider with the risk of spills from fuel use. Transition risk is important with issues related to climate change and changing consumer preferences. Systemic risk merits consideration in terms of the risks and challenges associated with air traffic control and cyber security.  Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and customer related hazards.

Contamination Risk: Airport and Related Services operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Airport industry comprises of airlines, passengers and cargo all needing a safe, functional and affordable airport infrastructure for operations to thrive. Airport infrastructure can be split into two categories: airside infrastructure and landside infrastructure. Airside infrastructure accommodates the movement of aircraft around the airport and includes aircraft parking aprons, taxiways, airfield lights and signs, navigational and visual aids and runways. Landside infrastructure accommodates the movement of ground-based vehicles and passengers, including access roads, parking lots, garages, aviation and non-aviation related businesses, support and terminal buildings. Air passenger traffic and the number of aircrafts handled by airports across the world is increasing every year, resulting in overcrowding and struggling airports. There is an increasing need to expand existing airport infrastructure to cater for future growth. It is predicted that demand is likely to grow in smaller cities which have plans to construct new airports and current airports look to make longer runways, more gate capacity and modernise air traffic control systems.

fields.name: Alcoholic Beverages
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Alcoholic Beverages are Energy Management; Water and Wastewater Management; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, packaging and waste from an environmental perspective and health & safety and consumer protection from a social perspective. Product packaging is a key consideration, for example the use of recycled glass for bottling and aluminium for canning and end of life recyclability and associated labelling for consumers is critical. Other trends are towards lightweight glass, removing plastic (e.g. can rings) and inclusion of PCR in secondary packaging. Health & safety at brewing and bottling plants and throughout the supply chain merits consideration. 

Contamination Risk: Alcoholic Beverages operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Alcoholic Beverages industry includes companies that brew, distill, and manufacture various alcoholic beverages, including beer, wine, and liquor. Companies in this industry transform agricultural products, including sugar, barley, and corn, into finished alcoholic beverages. The largest companies have global operations, with portfolios of numerous branded products. Levels of vertical integration within the industry vary due to regulation in different markets. Breweries generally have multiple manufacturing facilities to provide access to different markets, while vintners and distillers are typically located where they have a history of production.

fields.name: Apparel Accessories and Footwear
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Apparel, Accessories & Footwear are Product Quality & Safety; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to chemicals and water use and the recyclability of products from an environmental, and modern slavery, working conditions, fair pay, and health & safety from a social perspective, especially in developing countries. The use of chemicals; for instance for dyes and product finishes, creates a pollution risk, especially where less regulated. Likewise, there can be health implications where workers and local communities are exposed. Compliance with regulations such as the EU’s REACH Directive should be considered. Issues can be material specific, such as the water and agri-chemical intensity of cotton production and the use of conflict minerals in jewellery. Accreditations such as Global Organic Textile Standard can be a guide. The recyclability of products and the risk of microfibre leakage during washing cycles are becoming increasingly high profile issues. 

Contamination Risk: Apparel, Accessories & Footwear operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Apparel, Accessories & Footwear industry includes companies involved in the design, manufacturing, wholesaling, and retailing of various products, including men’s, women’s, and children’s clothing, handbags, jewellery, watches, and footwear. Products are largely manufactured by vendors in emerging markets, thereby allowing companies in the industry to primarily focus on design, wholesaling, marketing, supply chain management, and retail activities.

fields.name: Appliance Manufacturing
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Appliance Manufacturing are Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to raw materials sourcing and supply chain management, especially with conflict minerals and metals, from both an environmental and social perspective. In addition, pollution control and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental, and working conditions, fair pay and health and safety from a social perspective. 
The use of energy is a key consideration in terms of production, distribution and use of the appliance. Product design is identified by SASB; "built to last" designs, looking at repairability and the ease of recycling are becoming increasingly important. Some eco-design is driven by EU and other regulations. Global Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) schemes will be important for Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE) and the use of ozone depleting refrigerants, and current trends on post consumer takeback schemes and leasing products should also be considered.

Contamination Risk: Appliance Manufacturing operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Appliance Manufacturing industry includes companies involved in the design and manufacturing of household appliances and hand tools. The industry sells and manufactures products around the world, primarily selling products to consumers through retail locations.

fields.name: Asset Management and Custody Activities
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Asset Management & Custody Activities are Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Business Ethics; Systemic Rick Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing and access from a social, and transparency, compliance and cyber security from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. SASB identifies employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing. Historically, the sector has struggled to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Asset Management & Custody Activities operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Asset Management & Custody Activities industry is comprised of companies that manage investment portfolios on a commission or fee basis for institutional, retail, and high net-worth investors. In addition, firms in this industry provide wealth management, private banking, financial planning, and investment advisory and retail securities brokerage services. Investment portfolios and strategies may be diversified across multiple asset classes, which include, but are not limited to, equities, fixed income, and hedge fund investments. Specific companies are engaged in venture capital and private equity investments. The industry provides an essential service in assisting a range of customers from individual retail investors to large, institutional asset owners to meet specified investment goals. Companies in the industry range from large multi-national asset managers with a wide range of investable products, strategies, and asset classes to small boutique firms providing services to a very specific market niche. While large firms generally compete on the basis of management fees charged for their services as well as their potential to generate superior investment performance, the smaller firms generally compete on their ability to provide products and services geared towards individual clients to satisfy their diversification needs. The 2008 financial crisis and subsequent regulatory developments highlight the social impact of the industry in terms of providing fair advice to customers and managing risks at the entity, portfolio, and economy-wide levels. In addition, the collective impact of the industry on the allocation of capital creates a responsibility to integrate sustainability factors in investment decisions and management.

fields.name: Automobiles
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Automobiles are Product Quality & Safety; Labour Practices; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to energy management, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, pollution, waste management, water use, contaminated land, climate change and sustainable sourcing from an environmental perspective. Also, enforced/ child labour, working conditions, health & safety and fair pay from a social, and bribery and corruption and data and cyber security from a governance perspective. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. Consideration of climate change risks - flooding and other extreme weather events in the location, distribution network and supply chain, as well as transition risk and carbon pricing due to typically high levels of energy use in the sector. There is also a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of enforced and child labour. SASB identifies product safety and product design as key areas, which are important to minimise virgin material use and increase recyclability at end of life.

Contamination Risk: Automobiles operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Automobiles industry includes companies that manufacture passenger vehicles, light trucks, and motorcycles. Industry players design, build, and sell vehicles that run using a range of traditional and alternative fuels and powertrains. They sell these vehicles to dealers for consumer retail sales as well as sell directly to feet customers, including car rental and leasing companies, commercial fleets, and governments. Due to the global nature of this industry, nearly all companies have manufacturing facilities, assembly plants, and service locations in several countries around the world. The Automobiles industry is highly concentrated, with a few large manufacturers and a diversified supply chain. Given the industry’s reliance on natural resources and sensitivity to the business cycle, revenues are typically cyclical.

fields.name: Auto Parts
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Auto Parts are Energy Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency; Competitive Behaviour.

RiskHorizon would also then point to supply chain management, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and transition risk from an environmental; and health & safety, customer welfare and labour rights from a social perspective. SASB identifies hazardous materials as an area of importance, particularly during manufacture, servicing and movement of products. Also waste management, especially in the context of end-of-life and circularity considerations. Labour rights can be a concern, especially within manufacturing plants in high-risk countries. 

Contamination Risk: Auto Parts operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in the Auto Parts industry supply motor vehicle parts and accessories to original equipment manufacturers (OEM). Auto parts companies typically specialise in the manufacturing and assembly of certain parts or accessories, such as engine exhaust systems, alternative drivetrains, hybrid systems, catalytic converters, aluminium wheels (rims), tires, rearview mirrors, and onboard electrical and electronic equipment. Although the larger automotive industry includes several tiers of suppliers that provide parts and raw materials used to assemble motor vehicles, the scope of SASB’s Auto Parts industry includes only Tier 1 suppliers that supply parts directly to OEMs. The scope of the industry excludes captive suppliers, such as engine and stamping facilities, that are owned and operated by OEMs. Similarity, it excludes Tier 2 suppliers, which provide inputs for the Auto Parts industry.

fields.name: Biofuels
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Biofuels are Air Quality; Water and Wastewater Management; Employee Health & Safety; Labour Practices; Human Rights & Community Relations; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the application of Genetic Modification (GM) and chemicals, biodiversity, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management and climate change from an environmental; and worker rights and fair pricing from a social; and cybersecurity from a governance perspective. Understanding climate change risks is important, including crop growth, yield, water demand and flooding. Biodiversity impacts are also important in the context of land grabbing and loss of virgin forest and deforestation, including for cash crops such as soya and palm oil. High energy users and GHG emissions are important during manufacturing and distribution. Worker’s rights and the risks of forced/child labour are of key importance within this sector, as well as and fair contracts and payment of suppliers. Cyber security is also important to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Biofuels operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Biofuels industry consists of companies that produce biofuels and process raw materials for production. Biofuels are manufactured using organic feedstocks and are used primarily as transportation fuels. Companies typically source feedstocks, which include food, oil crops, and animal products, from agricultural product distributors. Ethanol and biodiesel are the most widely produced biofuels, while other types include biogas, bio-hydrogen, and synthetic biofuels, produced from a variety of organic feedstocks. Biofuels companies’ customers are chiefly fuel-blending and fuel-supply companies, including major integrated oil companies. While biofuels are produced worldwide, the publicly listed companies in the Biofuels industry operate primarily in the U.S., though some have minor operations abroad, notably in India, Brazil, and South Korea. Government regulations related to the use of renewable fuel are a significant demand driver in the industry.

fields.name: Biotechnology
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals are Human Rights & Community Relations; Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Supply Chain Management; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the use of chemicals, packaging, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and energy management from an environmental; and fair pay, working conditions, animal testing and ethical trading from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. 
The use of harmful/banned chemicals and biological inputs (e.g. micro-organisms), poses a risk for contaminating land. Animal testing and the conditions for human trials is another significant consideration. Product packaging including recycled content merits consideration for both the finished product and transit packaging (e.g. reusable crates). GHG emissions and energy use are likely to have impacts during production and distribution within this industry. Fair pay and working conditions are important considerations in relation to modern slavery prevalence. Cyber and data security is important to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals industry develops, manufactures, and markets a range of brand-name and generic medications. A significant portion of the industry is driven by research and development, a high risk of product failure during clinical trials, and the need to obtain regulatory approval. Concerns over pricing practices and consolidation within the sector have created downward pricing pressures. Demand for the industry’s products is largely driving by population demographics, rates of insurance coverage, disease profiles, and economic conditions.

fields.name: Building Products & Furnishings
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Building Products & Finishings are Energy Management; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to raw materials sourcing and supply chain management; especially conflict minerals and wood, from both an environmental and social perspective. In addition, pollution control and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental, and working conditions, fair pay and health and safety from a social perspective. Eco-design is increasing in importance, as is material traceability and supply chain transparency, with increasing prevalence of standards such as the Forestry Stewardship Council (FSC). GHG emissions are a significant consideration as they span production, distribution and embedded carbon of products. Increased focus will be on the repurposing of materials and buildings and on waste prevention and recycling in construction and building refurbishment.  

Contamination Risk: Building Products & Finishings operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Building Products & Furnishings industry comprises companies involved in the design and manufacturing of home improvement products, home and office furnishings, and structural wood building materials. The industry’s products include flooring, ceiling tiles, home and office furniture and fixtures, wood trusses, plywood, paneling, and lumber. Companies typically sell their products through distribution channels to retail stores or through independent or company-owned dealerships.

fields.name: Cable & Satellite
fields.description:
Cable & Satellite is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to access and affordability from a social perspective. In terms of customer welfare, this is most relevant to content and ensuring protection of minors from unsuitable materials including pornography, gambling and advertising. Other considerations include the consumption of resources and especially non-renewable materials and physical environmental damage associated with core cabling installation processes.

Contamination Risk: Cable & Satellite operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Cable companies build wired ("cable") connections to homes and businesses. They work to negotiate bulk deals with the owners of TV channels to pay a set fee per subscriber for each channel and then package those channels into different tiers of service at various price points. They also transmit data over the wired connections which allows them to offer high-speed internet and voice services. Satellite companies own (or lease space on) communications satellites that orbit the Earth. These satellites transmit TV signals that can be picked up by satellite dishes that are installed on each customer's property. They can also offer internet service but this tends to be slow and has a high latency because of the long distance between the satellite and the user.

fields.name: Car Rentals & Leasing
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Car Rental & Leasing are Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and transition risk from an environmental; health & safety, employee engagement and diversity & inclusion from a social; and selling practices and product labelling from a governance perspective. Transition risk has the potential to substantially effect the industry, particularly the movement away from petrol and diesel motors to electric and hybrid alternatives. Effective management of health & safety, employee engagement and diversity & inclusion is important to ensure staff safety, wellbeing and development. Selling practices and product labelling are relevant in the context of financial products and services that are often sold alongside the core business of vehicle leasing.

Contamination Risk: Car Rental & Leasing operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in this industry rent or lease passenger vehicles to customers. Car rentals are typically for periods of less than a month, while leases are for a year or more. The industry includes car-sharing business models where rentals are measured hourly and typically include subscription fees. Car rental companies operate out of airport locations, which serve business and leisure travellers, and out of neighbourhood locations, which mostly provide repair-shop and weekend rentals. The industry is concentrated, with several dominant market players, who operate globally using a franchise model. The growth of public transit and ride-sharing services in major metropolitan areas may represent a threat to the long-term profitability of the Car Rental & Leasing industry if customers chose to hail rides or take public transit rather than rent vehicles.

fields.name: Casinos & Gaming
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Casinos & Gaming are Energy Management; Customer Welfare; Employee Health & Safety; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to selling practices and product labelling (including advertising), bribery and corruption, business ethics, data privacy and cyber security from a governance perspective. From a environmental perspective, particularly for larger firms, energy use and therefore Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions can be of concern. Health and safety issues should consider both site based ergonomics issues, and staff wellbeing and mental health issues.

Contamination Risk: Casinos & Gaming operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Publicly held casinos and gaming companies operate gambling facilities and/or platforms, including brick-and-mortar casinos, riverboat casinos, online gambling websites, and racetracks. The broader industry in the U.S. is dominated by privately held Native American casinos, which significantly outnumber publicly held casinos. Native American casinos are generally owned and operated by tribes, but sometimes can be managed by commercial casino operators or other management companies. The industry is characterised by high levels of regulatory oversight, which represents the main barrier to entry for new operators. Fewer than half of U.S. states have legalised commercial casinos in some form, although industry regulation varies significantly worldwide.

fields.name: Chemicals
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Chemicals are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Human Rights & Community Relations; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to pollution, hazardous substances, conflict minerals and climate change from an environmental; child labour, working conditions and fair pay from a social; and bribery and corruption and cyber security from a governance perspective. Engagement with the local community is important, particularly in storage/use and transport of hazardous substances. Phasing out certain chemicals and requirement for replacements (e.g. EU's REACH Directive) will be significant. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding) in the location, distribution network and supply chain and sourcing challenges, particularly the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and potential forced/ child labour. Working conditions, fair pay and health checks are critical. Consideration of anti-bribery and corruption around contracts and fair pricing is significant. Cyber security is important to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Chemicals operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in the Chemicals industry transform organic and inorganic feedstocks into more than 70,000 diverse products with a range of industrial, pharmaceutical, agricultural, housing, automotive, and consumer applications. The industry is commonly segmented into basic (commodity) chemicals, agricultural chemicals, and specialty chemicals. Basic chemicals, the largest segment by volume produced, include bulk polymers, petrochemicals, inorganic chemicals, and other industrial chemicals. Agricultural chemicals include fertilisers, crop chemicals, and agricultural biotechnology. Specialty chemicals include paints and coatings, agrochemicals, sealants, adhesives, dyes, industrial gases, resins, and catalysts. Larger firms may produce basic, agricultural, and specialty chemicals, while most companies are specialised. Chemicals companies typically manufacture and sell products globally.

fields.name: Coal Operations
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Coal Operations are GHG Emissions; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Ecological Impacts; Human Rights & Community Relations; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Business Model Resilience.

RiskHorizon would also then point to bribery and corruption from a governance, transition risk from an environmental, and the risk of child/ forced labour from a social perspective. SASB considers the risk of child labour to be low, however RiskHorizon would caution that this could be of concern in developing countries or within such companies’ supply chains. As global governments and businesses transition to a zero carbon future, demand for coal is commonly predicted to decrease.

Contamination Risk: Coal Operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Coal Operations industry includes companies that mine coal and those that manufacture coal products. Mining activity covers both underground and surface mining, and thermal and metallurgical coal.

fields.name: Commercial Banks
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Commercial Banks are Data Security; Access & Affordability; Product Design & Lifecycle Management;  Business Ethics; Systemic Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing, access and employee engagement from a social, and transparency and compliance and cyber security, from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Commercial Banks operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Commercial banks accept deposits and make loans to individuals and corporations as well as engage in lending for infrastructure, real estate, and other projects. By providing these services, the industry serves an essential role in the functioning of global economies and in facilitating the transfer of financial resources to their most productive capacity. The industry is driven by the volume of deposits, quality of loans made, the economic environment, and interest rates. It is further characterised by risk from mismatched assets and liabilities. The regulatory environment that governs the commercial banking industry saw significant changes in the wake of the financial crisis of 2008 and continues to evolve today. These and other regulatory trends have the potential to impact shareholder value and sustainability performance. Commercial banks with global operations must manage new regulations in multiple jurisdictions that are creating regulatory uncertainty, particularly around consistent application of new rules.

fields.name: Commercial Printing
fields.description:
Commercial Printing is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to supply chain management, materials sourcing, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, waste management, hazardous materials and water management from an environmental; and health & safety and labour rights from a social perspective. Materials sourcing has the potential for significant impact, especially with chemicals, paper and board. Waste management is important, particularly with end of life and circularity of products and processes. Hazardous materials pose as a risk, especially during manufacturing stages. Consideration of wastewater and effluents is important, as well as water use in water stress areas. Additionally, labour rights is significant to explore, especially in manufacturing plants in high risk countries.

Contamination Risk: Commercial Printing operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Commercial Printing is the process of transferring artwork to a piece of paper or card so it can used to produce a wide variety of products. There is typically four types of commercial printing: Offset Lithography - best used by businesses for an extensive product range, Digital - most used for labels, letters, newsletter, banners and menus, Large Format - best used for signage, wallpaper, floor graphics, pop-up displays, exhibitions and billboards and finally LED UV - best used for high quality prospectuses, handbooks, magazines, posters and brochures. There has been an increased demand for commercial printing and promotional materials from the retail, food and beverage industries, which is mainly driving the market, particularly print advertising. Introduction of eco-friendly practices, reducing the printing industry’s impact on the environment drives the market. Several new initiatives such as vegetable inks are being implemented which are environment-friendly inks made from vegetable oils. Such inks are considered better in terms of performance because of drastically reducing the amount of VOCs as these are prepared from the vegetable oils.

fields.name: Construction Materials
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Construction Materials are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Ecological Impacts; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Competitive Behaviour.

RiskHorizon would also then point to raw materials sourcing and supply chain management; especially conflict minerals and wood, from both an environmental and social perspective. In addition, pollution control from an environmental, and working conditions and fair pay from a social perspective. Eco-design is increasing in importance, as is material traceability and supply chain transparency, with increasing prevalence of standards such as the Forestry Stewardship Council (FSC). Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions are a significant consideration as they span production, distribution and embedded carbon of products. Increased focus will be on the repurposing of materials and buildings and on waste prevention and recycling in construction and building refurbishment.

Contamination Risk: Construction Materials operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Construction materials companies have global operations and produce construction materials for sale to construction firms or wholesale distributors. These primarily include cement and aggregates, but also glass, plastic materials, insulation, bricks, and roofing material. Materials producers operate their own quarries, mining crushed stone or sand and gravel. They may also purchase raw materials from the mining and petroleum industries. Note: Companies producing wood-building products are included the Building Products & Furnishings (CG-BF) industry, Forestry Management industry (RR-FM), and Pulp & Paper Products industry (RR-PP) under the Sustainable Industry Classification System (SICS) and are not included in the Construction Materials standard.

fields.name: Consumer Finance
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Consumer Finance are Customer Privacy; Data Security; Selling Practices & Product Labelling.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing, access and employee engagement from a social, and transparency and compliance and cyber security, from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Consumer Finance operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Consumer Finance industry provides loans to consumers. The largest segment of the industry is comprised of revolving credit loans through credit card products. Additional loan services include auto, micro lending, and student loans. Some companies in the industry also provide consumer-to-consumer money transfers, money orders, prepaid debit cards, and bill payment services. Industry performance is determined by consumer spending, rates of unemployment, per capita GDP, income, and population growth. Recent shifts toward consumer protection and transparency have aligned and will continue to align the interests of society with those of long-term investors. Companies that effectively manage their social capital will therefore be better positioned to maximise their financial capital.

fields.name: Containers and Packaging
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Containers & Packaging are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to pollution, sustainable sourcing, circularity and climate change from an environmental; and health & safety and employee engagement from a social perspective. Pollution is likely to have impacts during production. There are potential sourcing risks around the use of virgin materials, notably sustainably grown timber and the associated land use impact. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding) in the location, distribution network and supply chain. SASB identifies product design considerations, including recycled sources, weighting, product preservation and material bans. Confusion over bioplastic, NGO scrutiny and high consumer expectation, often in low margin applications are all important. Finally, there is a desire to understand and influence down-stream destinations and traceability for materials post use. Health & safety is also important, as well as employee engagement.

Contamination Risk: Containers & Packaging operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Containers & Packaging industry converts raw materials, including metal, plastic, paper, and glass, into semi-finished or finished packaging products. Companies produce a wide range of products, including: corrugated cardboard packaging, food and beverage containers, bottles for household products, aluminium cans, steel drums, and other forms of packaging. Companies in the industry typically function as business-to-business entities and many operate globally.

fields.name: Cruise Liners
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Cruise Liners are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Ecological Impacts; product Quality & Safety; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Critical Incident Risk Management. 

RiskHorizon would then also point to pollution risk and climate change from an environmental, and modern slavery, migrant workers and trafficking risks from a social perspective. Regarding pollution, this is relevant from the perspective of vessels at sea and at port (including sewage, waste and oil) under normal operations and during emergency situations. The cruise line industry typically employs large numbers of migrant workers which requires enhanced governance to mitigate associated risks.

Contamination Risk: Cruise Liners operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Cruise Lines industry comprises companies that provide passenger transportation and leisure entertainment, including deep sea cruises and river cruises. The industry is dominated by a few large companies. Cruises aim to provide a luxury resort experience for thousands of passengers at a time. The Cruise Lines industry has often been the fastest-growing segment of the travel industry, but is very cyclical.

fields.name: Drug Retailers & Convenience Stores
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Drug Retailers are Energy Management; Data Security; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the use of chemicals, packaging and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental; and ethical trading, animal testing and workers rights from a social perspective. The use of harmful/banned chemicals, as well as biological inputs (e.g. use of micro-organisms), poses a risk for contaminating land. Considerations of palm oil and the ethical practices during the sourcing processes is important. Animal testing and the conditions for human trials is another significant consideration. Product packaging including recycled content merits consideration for both the finished product and transit packaging (e.g. reusable crates). GHG emissions and the use of energy are likely to have significant impacts during production and distribution within this industry. Fair pay and working conditions are important when considering the prevalence of modern slavery.

Contamination Risk: Drug Retailers operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Drug Retailers industry comprises companies that operate retail pharmacies and distribution centres that supply retail stores. Stores may be company-owned or franchised. Large companies operate mainly in the U.S. and source drugs and other merchandise through wholesalers and distributors. The majority of the industry’s revenues are derived from consumer sales of prescription and over-the-counter pharmaceutical products; other goods sold include household goods, personal care products, and a limited selection of groceries. Additionally, the pharmacy retailer segment is expanding its health-focused services by offering clinics at various retail locations, which adds to the industry’s shifting sustainability landscape.

fields.name: E-commerce
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with E-Commerce are Energy Management; Customer Privacy; Data Security; Product Design & Lifecycle Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to ethical trading and materials sourcing from an environmental and social perspective. The increased use of recycled materials, pollution, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and packaging are important from an environmental and working conditions, fair pay and health & safety from a social perspective. Materials sourcing and supply chain management is especially important for conflict minerals, metals and regulated chemicals. Packaging and the plastics agenda is rapidly gaining momentum, with trends towards refillable and recyclable packaging, increased scrutiny on logistics impacts and recyclability messaging on packaging. Product loss or waste from customer returns is a particular issue in some product lines. 

Contamination Risk: E-Commerce operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The E-Commerce industry is composed of forms that provide an online marketplace for other firms or individuals to sell their goods and services, as well as retailers and wholesalers that provide an exclusively web-based platform for consumers to buy goods and services. Firms in this industry sell to consumers as well as to other businesses. Because of the accessibility of e-commerce sites, the industry is a global marketplace for buyers and sellers. Note: The industry scope exclusively applies to “pure-play” e-commerce operations and does not address the manufacturing or brick-and-mortar retail operations of companies. Many consumer goods manufacturers and retailers have incorporated, or are in the process of incorporating, an e-commerce component to their business. SASB has separate standards for the Multiline and Specialty Retailers & Distributors (CG-MR); Apparel, Accessories & Footwear (CG-AA); and Toys & Sporting Goods (CG-TS) industries. Depending on the specific activities and operations of firms in the aforementioned industries, disclosure topics and accounting metrics associated with the E-Commerce industry standard may also be relevant.

fields.name: Education
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Education are Data Security; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & product Labelling.

RiskHorizon would also then point to access and affordability, staff wellbeing, recruitment and retention from a social perspective. From a environmental perspective, particularly for larger institutions, energy use and therefore Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions can be of concern. Health and safety issues should consider both site based ergonomics issues, and staff wellbeing and mental health issues.

Contamination Risk: Education operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Education industry includes education institutions that are profit-seeking and generate revenue from student fees. At the primary and secondary levels, this includes mostly education management organisations (EMOs) and some businesses. At the tertiary (or higher) level, services are delivered on a full-time, part-time, distance-learning, and occasional basis across establishments such as junior colleges, business and secretarial schools, colleges, universities, and professional schools including medical, pharmaceutical, and veterinary programs. An increasing number of students in for-profit universities take courses online.

fields.name: Electrical & Electronic Equipment
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Electrical & Electronic Equipment are Energy Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency; Business Ethics. 

RiskHorizon would also then point to environmental compliance and climate change from an environmental; supply chain management from an environmental and social; and labour rights and health & safety from a social perspective. SASB identifies waste management as a key risk, which is important for considering end of life and circularity of products and services. Other manufacturing impacts include the risks involved in using hazardous materials, wastewater generation and treatment, energy and water use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. Consideration of climate change risks - flooding and other extreme weather events in the location, distribution network and supply chain. There is also a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of enforced and child labour. 

Contamination Risk: Electrical & Electronic Equipment operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Electrical & Electronic Equipment industry consists of companies that develop and manufacture a broad range of electric components, including power generation equipment, energy transformers, electric motors, switchboards, automation equipment, heating and cooling equipment, lighting, and transmission cables. These include: non-structural commercial and residential building equipment, such as Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) systems, lighting fixtures, security devices, and elevators; electrical power equipment; traditional power generation and transmission equipment; renewable energy equipment; industrial automation controls; measurement instruments; and electrical components used for industrial purposes, such as coils, wires, and cables. Companies in this mature and competitive industry operate globally and typically generate a significant portion of their revenue from outside the country of their domicile.

fields.name: Electric Utilities
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Electric Utilities & Power Generators are GHG Emissions; Air Quality, Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Access & Affordability; Employee Health & Safety; Business Model Resilience; Critical Incident Risk Management; Systemic Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to employee engagement and fair pricing from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. SASB identifies water as an important factor and RiskHorizon would include the volumes but temperatures of discharged water and the impact on the receiving waters, notably for biodiversity. Waste management is also recognised by SASB, which relates to risks associated with fly ash. Fair pricing and contracts are important considerations within this sector to suppliers. Data and cyber security poses a risk, particularly with relation to remote operating systems. 

Contamination Risk: Electric Utilities & Power Generators operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Electric Utilities & Power Generators industry is made up of companies that generate electricity; build, own, and operate transmission and distribution (T&D) lines; and sell electricity. Utilities generate electricity from a number of different sources, commonly including coal, natural gas, nuclear energy, hydropower, solar, wind, and other renewable and fossil fuel energy sources. The industry comprises companies operating in both regulated and unregulated business structures. Regulated utilities maintain a business model in which they accept comprehensive oversight from regulators on their pricing mechanisms and their allowed return on equity, among other types of regulation, in exchange for their license to operate as a monopoly. Unregulated companies, or merchant power companies, are often independent power producers (IPPs) that generate electricity to sell to the wholesale market, which includes regulated utility buyers and other end-users. Furthermore, the industry is divided across regulated and deregulated power markets—referring to how far up the value chain regulated utility operations span. Regulated markets typically contain vertically integrated utilities that own and operate everything from the generation of power to its retail distribution. Deregulated markets commonly split generation from distribution, designed to encourage competition at the wholesale power level. Overall, companies in the industry are challenged with the complex mission of providing reliable, accessible, low-cost power while balancing the protection of human life and the environment.

fields.name: Electronic Manufacturing Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Electronic Manufacturing Services and Original Design Manufacturing are Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to environmental compliance and climate change from an environmental and supply chain management from an environmental and social perspective. SASB identifies waste management as a key risk, which is important for considering end of life and circularity of products and services. Other manufacturing impacts include the risks involved in using hazardous materials, wastewater generation and treatment, energy and water use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. Consideration of climate change risks - flooding and other extreme weather events in the location, distribution network and supply chain. There is also a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of enforced and child labour. 

Contamination Risk:  Electronic Manufacturing Services and Original Design Manufacturing operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: EMS companies provide assembly, logistics, and after-market services for original equipment manufacturers. The ODM segment of the industry provides engineering and design services for original equipment manufacturers and may own significant intellectual property. Although EMS & ODM companies produce equipment for a variety of sectors, the industry is closely associated with the Hardware industry, which consists of companies that design technology hardware products such as personal computers, consumer electronics, and storage devices for both personal consumers and businesses. Note: The Electronic Manufacturing Services & Original Design Manufacturing industry does not include the design of technology hardware products. Companies that design and manufacture technology hardware products should consider the separate SASB Hardware Industry Standard (TC-HW) in addition to the SASB Electronic Manufacturing Services & Original Design Manufacturing Industry Standard (TC-ES).

fields.name: Engineering & Construction Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Engineering & Construction Services are Ecological Impacts; Product Quality & Safety; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management;  Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to recycled materials, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management and climate change from an environmental; and fair pricing and working conditions from a social perspective. Recycled materials, including use of virgin compared to recycled materials (e.g. certified timber) is key to consider. Also, the awareness of durability of build "built to last" and the repairability compared to disposable and easily recyclable capabilities. GHG emissions and energy use are important during production, distribution and embedded carbon phases. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding) in both the siting and design. Other build design factors, including accessibility, energy use and recycled materials used in partitioning are all significant factors. Fair pricing and contracts are important, as well as anti-bribery and corruption.

Contamination Risk: Engineering & Construction Services operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Engineering & Construction Services industry provides engineering, construction, design, consulting, contracting, and other related services that support various building and infrastructure projects. The industry is primarily made up of four major segments: engineering services, infrastructure construction, non-residential building construction, and building sub-contractors and construction-related professional services. The infrastructure construction segment includes companies that design and/or build infrastructure projects such as power plants, dams, oil and gas pipelines, refineries, highways, bridges, tunnels, railways, ports, airports, waste treatment plants, water networks, and stadiums. The non-residential building construction segment includes companies that design and/or build industrial and commercial facilities such as factories, warehouses, data centres, offices, hotels, hospitals, universities, and retail spaces like malls. The engineering services segment includes companies that provide specialised architectural and engineering services such as design and development of feasibility studies for many of the project types listed above. Finally, the building sub-contractors and other construction-related professional services segment includes smaller companies that provide ancillary services such as carpentry, electrical, plumbing, painting, waterproofing, landscaping, interior design, and building inspection. The industry’s customers include infrastructure owners and developers in the public and private sectors. Large companies in this industry operate and generate revenue globally and typically specialise in multiple segments

fields.name: Facilities Management and Pollution Control Services
fields.description:
Facilities Management and Pollution Control Services is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, hazardous materials, pollution and biodiversity impact from an environmental, and labour practices including modern slavery prevalence, worker health & safety and staff development and retention, from a social perspective. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving) and activities on operational sites.

Contamination Risk: Facilities Management and Pollution Control Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Facilities Management and Pollution Control Services industry operates in sectors including municipal, commercial, agricultural, industrial and domestic and offers a wide-ranging of services. The Facilities Management sector encompasses companies engaged in a wide range of soft and hard service provision in both the private and public sector. Hard FM includes planning, design, workplace, construction, lease, occupancy, maintenance and furniture. Soft FM includes catering, cleaning, ICT, HR, accounting, marketing and hospitality. It is the total management of all services and built environment infrastructure that support the core business of an organisation. Companies are increasingly outsourcing facilities management. The Pollution Control services industry encompasses companies that provide a wide range of auxiliary equipment and services to help with pollution control. The industry provides a specialist range of monitoring, investigation and enforcement services covering air pollution and air quality, contaminated land, noise and vibration and water pollution. It also includes the work and services from councils who aim to protect public health and the environment through enforcement of legislation and the provision of advice and information to the public.

fields.name: Food Retailers & Distributors
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Food Retailers & Distributors are GHG Emissions; Energy Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Data Security; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Labour Practices; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to climate change, biodiversity and packaging and from an environmental; and fair contracts, worker's rights and customer welfare from a social perspective. Understanding climate change impacts is important, including crop growth, yield, water demand and availability and flooding. Biodiversity impacts are also important for loss of virgin forest and deforestation, including for cash crops such as soya and palm oil. Packaging for goods sold and transit of goods merits consideration, particularly plastic bag and material bans, such as single-use plastic (SUP) on plastic straws. Innovation trends around packaging waste prevention, via packaging free initiatives, with a focus on reusable or refillable. Consideration of physical stores and risks of flooding, accessibility, asbestos and shop fitting, as well as staff pay and zero hours contracts. 

Contamination Risk: Food Retailers & Distributors operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Food Retailers & Distributors industry consists of companies engaged in wholesale and retail sales of food, beverage, and agricultural products. Store formats include retail supermarkets, convenience stores, warehouse supermarkets, liquor stores, bakeries, natural food stores, specialty food stores, seafood stores, and distribution centres. Companies may specialise in one type of store format or have facilities that contain multiple formats. Products are typically sourced worldwide and include fresh meat and produce, prepared foods, processed foods, baked goods, frozen and canned foods, nonalcoholic and alcoholic beverages, and a wide selection of household goods and personal care products.

fields.name: Forestry & Logging
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Forestry Management are Ecological Impacts; Human Rights & Community Relations; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management and land rights from an environmental; and health & safety, working conditions and fair pricing from a social perspective.
GHG emissions and energy use are important for consideration during harvesting, processing and distribution. Biodiversity and soil health are likely to have impacts on erosion, therefore, reforestation practices and product certification are important here. Conflicting land use, such as land grabbing and use of land for forestry over food production for local communities is an rea of high importance. This makes community engagement significant. Employee and sub-contractor health & safety is critical, as well as working conditions and the potential risk of forced/child labour, particularly with sub-contractors. Fair pricing and contracts are important, as well as anti-bribery and corruption.

Contamination Risk: Forestry Management operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Forestry Management industry consists of companies that own and/or manage natural and planted forestry lands and timber tracts, or operate non-retail tree nurseries and rubber plantations . The industry conducts its operations on lands that can be company-owned or leased from public or private landowners. Companies typically sell timber to wood products manufacturers, pulp and paper producers, energy producers, and a variety of other customers. The industry’s largest companies operate primarily in and are domiciled in the U.S. and Canada. Some have international operations including in Brazil and New Zealand. While some integrated companies may also operate sawmills, wood products facilities, or pulp and paper facilities, sustainability issues arising from these activities are addressed in SASB’s Building Products & Furnishings (CG-BP) and Pulp & Paper Products (RR-PP) industry standards.

fields.name: Fuel Cells and Industrial Batteries
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Fuel Cells & Industrial Batteries are Energy Management; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, pollution, sustainable sourcing and waste management from an environmental; and product safety, transparency, child labour and fair pricing from a social perspective. There is a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and potential conflict minerals, with the associated environmental and social impacts, including pollution impacts to land and risk of forced/ child labour. A fully transparent supply chain is important to consider. Employee engagement is also important for ensuring staff development and wellbeing. Product safety and product design are significant to minimising virgin material use and increasing recyclability at end of life, and the ability to implement take back schemes. Consideration of fair pricing and contracts of suppliers to large and/or single clients is also important. 

Contamination Risk: Fuel Cells & Industrial Batteries operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description:
The Fuel Cells & Industrial Batteries industry consists of companies that manufacture fuel cells for energy production and energy storage equipment such as batteries. Manufacturers in this industry mainly sell products to companies for varied energy-generation and energy-storage applications and intensities, from commercial business applications to large-scale energy projects for utilities. Companies in the industry typically have global operations and sell products to a global marketplace. 
Note: For the purposes of SASB standards, this industry does not include fuel cells or batteries used in light automotive vehicle applications. See SASB standards for the Auto Parts industry (TR-AP) for details on reporting this business segment. This industry also does not include non-industrial batteries for personal consumer use, which are classified under the Household & Personal Products industry (CG-HP)

fields.name: Gas Utilities
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Gas Utilities & Distributors are Access & Affordability; Business Model Resilience;  Critical Incident Risk Management.
