RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental; and health & safety and fair pricing from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. Employee health & safety is critical to consider within this sector, as well as the safety of local communities. Employee engagement is also important for considering staff development and wellbeing. Fair pricing and contracts poses a risk within this sector, as well as anti-bribery and corruption. Consideration of data and cyber security particularly with remote operating systems is important here. 

Contamination Risk: Gas Utilities & Distributors operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Gas Utilities & Distributors industry is made up of gas distribution and marketing companies. Gas distribution involves operating local, low-pressure pipes to transfer natural gas from larger transmission pipes to end users. Gas marketing companies are gas brokers that aggregate natural gas into quantities that ft the needs of their different customers and then deliver it, generally through other companies’ transmission and distribution lines. A relatively smaller portion of this industry is involved in propane gas distribution; therefore this standard is focused on natural gas distribution. Both types of gas are commonly used for heating and cooking by residential, commercial, and industrial customers. In structurally regulated markets, the utility is granted a full monopoly over the distribution and sale of natural gas. A regulator must approve the rates utilities charge to avoid the abuse of their monopoly position. In deregulated markets, distribution and marketing are legally separated and customers have a choice of which company to buy their gas from. In this case, a utility is guaranteed a monopoly only over distribution and is legally required to transmit all gas equitably along its pipes for a fixed fee. Overall, companies in the industry are tasked with providing safe, reliable, low-cost gas, while effectively managing their social and environmental impacts, such as community safety and methane emissions. Note: The SASB Gas Utilities & Distributors industry does not include gas transmission companies that transport highly pressurised natural gas over long distances from the wellhead. Gas transmission companies are included in the Oil & Gas - Midstream industry (EM-MD) in the Extractives & Minerals Processing sector.

fields.name: Hardware
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Hardware are Data Security; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to waste management, end of life and circularity from an environmental, and health & safety and labour rights from a social perspective.  The design of consumer goods is coming under increasing scrutiny in terms of recycled content, reusability and ease of recycling/ repurposing. Also, the inclusion of hazardous materials, rare earth metals and conflict minerals is an important consideration. 

Contamination Risk: Hardware operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Hardware industry consists of companies that design and sell technology hardware products, including computers, consumer electronics, communications equipment, storage devices, components, and peripherals. Many companies in the industry rely heavily on the Electronic Manufacturing Services & Original Design Manufacturing (EMS & ODM) industry for manufacturing services. The industry is expected to continue to grow as the use of technology rapidly grows, especially from consumers in emerging markets. Note: Companies engaged in activities of the Software & IT Services industry (TC-SI), Internet Media & Services (TC-IM) industry, and/or the EMS & ODM industry (TC-ES) should consider the separate SASB standards for these industries.

fields.name: Healthcare Delivery
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Healthcare Delivery are Energy Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Data Security; Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & product Labelling; Employee Health & Safety; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Physical Impacts of Climate Change; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to circularity and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental; and working conditions from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. Considerations on circularity, with a focus on disposables, consumables, the use of recycled items and volume of disposable items are significant. GHG emissions and energy use in large settings, such as hospitals is important to consider. Working conditions poses a risk, including fair pay, the prevalence of zero-hour contracts and worker’s rights, especially for support staff such as cleaners. There is also a high potential of modern slavery within this sector. SASB identifies customer welfare as important and this relates to client/ patient care, including ethics and safeguarding, particularly vulnerable patients. Cyber and data security is also significant to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Healthcare Delivery operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Health Care Delivery industry owns and manages hospitals, clinics, and other health care-related facilities. Companies provide a range of services, including inpatient and outpatient care, surgery, mental health, rehabilitation, and clinical laboratory services. Demand for health care delivery services is driven largely by rates of insurance coverage, demographics, illness, and injury rates. The U.S. Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) increased the number of individuals with insurance, however, the future of this legislation remains uncertain. The industry is characterised by high fixed labor and facilities costs, and an increased regulatory emphasis on reduced costs of care and improved outcomes. Health care delivery companies also face significant competition for patients and resources from private, non-profit, and religious health care systems.

fields.name: Healthcare Distribution
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Healthcare Distributors are GHG Emissions; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Product Design & Lifecycle Management;  Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to packaging from an environmental; and ethical trading, fair pay and working conditions from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. The sourcing of palm oil is important in relation to the ethical trade issues that can arise during the sourcing processes. Product packaging is important for including recycled content and producing recyclable and/ or refillable products, which considers both the finished product but the transit packaging (e.g. reusable crates). GHG emissions and energy use are important during production and distribution within this sector. Fair pay and workers right and conditions merits consideration, as well as fair pricing and contracts. Cyber and data security is significant to ensure safety of systems and minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Healthcare Distributors operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Health care distributors purchase, inventory, and sell pharmaceutical products and medical equipment to hospitals, pharmacies, and physicians. Demand for the industry’s services is driven largely by rates of insurance, pharmaceutical spending, illness, and demographics. Increased enrolment in government insurance programs under the U.S Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, electronic health records, and consolidation throughout the Health Care sector will likely continue to shape the industry. The health care sector continues to face an emphasis on reduced costs and improved efficiencies, which will also impact the Health Care Distributors industry. Companies in this industry face challenges from consolidation and partnerships between pharmacies, payers, and manufacturers.

fields.name: Home Builders
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Home Builders are Ecological Impacts; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Business Model Resilience.

RiskHorizon would also then point to material sourcing, recycled materials, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management and climate change from an environmental; and health & safety, working conditions and fair pricing from a social perspective. Recycled materials, including virgin compared to recycled materials (e.g. certified timber) is important and the durability of build "built to last" and the repairability compared to disposable and easily recyclable capabilities. GHG emissions and energy use are important during production, distribution and embedded carbon phases. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding) in the siting and design. Build design factors, including accessibility, energy, recyclability and use of natural light are all important. Health & safety is important, including sub-contractor and end-user safety and employee working conditions, with potential risk of forced/child labour, particularly with sub-contractors.

Contamination Risk: Home Builders operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Home Builders industry is comprised of companies that develop new homes and residential communities. Development efforts generally include the acquisition of land, site preparation, the construction of homes, and home sales. The majority of industry activity is focused on the development and sale of single-family homes, which are typically part of company-designed residential communities. A smaller segment is centred on townhomes, condominiums, multi-family housing, and mixed-use development. Many companies in the industry offer financing services to individual homebuyers. The industry is fragmented, as there is a large number of developers of all sizes, which vary in company structure and geographic focus. Listed companies tend to be significantly larger, and more integrated than the numerous privately held home builders.

fields.name: Hotels & Lodging
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Hotels & Lodging are Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Ecological Impacts; Labour Practices; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, waste management, ecological impacts, supply chain management and climate change from an environmental perspective;  customer welfare and modern slavery from a social; and data privacy from a governance perspective. The physical impacts of climate change might include increased temperatures increasing the cooling demand and more extreme weather leading to flooding and building damage. Additionally, modern slavery prevalence and labour rights are material considerations.

Contamination Risk: Hotels & Lodging operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Hotels & Lodging industry is composed of companies that provide overnight accommodation, including hotels, motels, and inns. It is a competitive industry that is primarily comprised of large hotel chains and in which customers base purchase decisions on a wide range of factors including quality and consistency of services, availability of locations, price, and loyalty program offers. Businesses are often structured in one or more of the following ways: direct revenue from hotel services, including room rental and food and beverage sales; management and franchise services with fee revenue from property management; and vacation residential ownership with revenue from sales of residential units.

fields.name: Household & Personal Products
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Household & Personal Products are Water & Wastewater Management; Product Quality & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the use of chemicals, pollution, packaging, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and energy management from an environmental, and animal testing, working conditions, ethical trading and sourcing from a social perspective. The avoidance of palm oil and microplastics in cosmetics are key examples of the supply chain issues requiring consideration. Packaging and the plastics agenda is rapidly gaining momentum, with trends towards refillable and recyclable packaging and the inclusion of post-consumer resin (PCR) in products, in particular, coming under increased focus. Furthermore some items will be impacted by regulatory restrictions such as plastic cutlery and straws in the EU. 

Contamination Risk: Household & Personal Products operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Household & Personal Products industry comprises companies that manufacture a wide range of goods for personal and commercial consumption, including cosmetics, household and industrial cleaning supplies, soaps and detergents, sanitary paper products, household batteries, razors, and kitchen utensils. Household and personal products companies operate globally and typically sell their products to mass merchants, grocery stores, membership club stores, drug stores, high-frequency stores, distributors, and e-commerce retailers. Some companies sell products through independent representatives rather than third-party retail establishments.

fields.name: Industrial Machinery & Goods
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Industrial Machinery & Goods are Energy Management; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to environmental compliance and climate change from an environmental and supply chain management from an environmental and social perspective. Manufacturing impacts include the risks involved in using hazardous materials, wastewater generation and treatment, waste, energy and water use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. Consideration of climate change risks - flooding and other extreme weather events in the location, distribution network and supply chain. There is also a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of enforced and child labour. 

Contamination Risk: Industrial Machinery & Goods operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Industrial Machinery & Goods industry manufactures equipment for a variety of industries including construction, agriculture, energy, utility, mining, manufacturing, automotive, and transportation. Products include engines, earth-moving equipment, trucks, tractors, ships, industrial pumps, locomotives, and turbines. Machinery manufacturers utilise large amounts of raw materials for production, including steel, plastics, rubber, paints, and glass. Manufacturers may also perform the machining and casting of parts before final assembly. Demand in the industry is closely tied to industrial production, while government emissions standards and customer demand are driving innovations to improve energy efficiency and limit air emissions during product use

fields.name: Insurance
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Insurance are Selling Practices & product Labelling; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Physical Impacts of Climate Change; Systemic Rick Management. 

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing, access and employee engagement from a social, and transparency and compliance and cyber security, from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Insurance operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Insurance industry provides both traditional and nontraditional insurance-related products. Traditional policy lines include property, life, casualty, and reinsurance. Nontraditional products include annuities, alternative risk transfers, and financial guarantees. Companies in the insurance industry also engage in proprietary investments. Insurance companies generally operate within a single segment in the industry, e.g., property and casualty, although there are some large insurance companies with diversified operations. Similarly, companies may vary based on the level of their geographic segmentation. While large companies may underwrite insurance premiums in multiple countries, smaller companies generally operate at a national or even local level. Insurance premiums, underwriting revenue, and investment income drive industry growth, while insurance claim payments present the most significant cost and source of uncertainty for profits. Insurance companies provide products and services that enable the transfer, pooling, and sharing of risk necessary for a well-functioning economy. Insurance companies, through their products, can also create a form of moral hazard, lowering incentives to improve underlying behavior and performance, and thus contributing to sustainability impacts. Similar to other financial institutions, insurance companies face risks associated with credit and financial markets. Within the industry, companies that engage in non-traditional or non-insurance activities, including credit default swaps (CDS) protection and debt securities insurance, have been identified by regulators as being more vulnerable to financial market developments, and subsequently, more likely to amplify or contribute to systemic risk. As a result, insurance companies face the potential of being designated as Systemically Important Financial Institutions, thus exposing them to enhanced regulation and oversight.

fields.name: Internet & Media Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Internet Media & Services are Energy Management; Customer Privacy; Data Security; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Competitive Behaviour.

RiskHorizon would also then point to water management and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental, and selling practices and customer welfare from a governance perspective. SASB identifies energy management as being a key risk, which has particular importance within data centres, as traditionally large users of energy. Water use  can also be significant, particularly when related to the cooling of data centres. In terms of customer welfare, this is most relevant to content and ensuring protection of minors from unsuitable materials including pornography, gambling and advertising. 

Contamination Risk: Internet Media & Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Internet Media & Services industry consists of two main segments. The Internet Media segment includes companies providing search engines and internet advertising channels, online gaming, and online communities such as social networks, as well as content, usually easily searchable, such as educational, medical, health, sports, or news content. The Internet-based Services segment includes companies selling services mainly through the Internet. The industry generates revenues primarily from online advertising, on usually free content, with other sources of revenue being subscription fees, content sales, or sale of user information to interested third parties.

fields.name: Investment Banking and Brokerage
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Investment Banking & Brokerage are Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Business Ethics; Systemic Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing, access and employee engagement from a social, and transparency and compliance and cyber security, from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Investment Banking & Brokerage operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Investment Banking & Brokerage industry consists of firms performing a wide range of functions in the capital markets, including assisting with the capital-raising and allocation process, and providing market-making and advisory services for corporations, financial institutions, governments, and high net-worth individuals. Specific activities include financial advisory and securities underwriting services conducted on a fee basis; securities and commodities brokerage activities, which involves buying and selling securities or commodities contracts and options on a commission or fee basis for investors; and trading and principal investment activities, which involves the buying and selling of equities, fixed income, currencies, commodities, and other securities for client-driven and proprietary trading. Investment banks also originate and securitise loans for infrastructure and other projects. Companies in the industry generate their revenues from global markets and, therefore, are exposed to various regulatory environments. The industry continues to face regulatory pressure to reform and disclose aspects of operations that present systemic risks. Specifically, firms are facing new capital requirements, stress testing, limits on proprietary trading, and increased scrutiny on compensation practices.

fields.name: Iron & Steel Producers
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Iron & Steel Producers are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Employee Health & Safety; Supply Chain Management.

Risk Horizon would also then point to workers rights, potential use of forced/child labour, working conditions, fair pay and health checks/ screening from a social, and bribery and corruption, from a governance perspective. Carbon pricing and transition risk are important considerations due to very high energy users within this sector. Bribery and corruption are key considerations, particularly around contracts and fair pricing. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. 

Contamination Risk: Iron & Steel Producers operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Iron & Steel Producers industry consists of steel producers with iron and steel mills and companies with iron and steel foundries. The steel producers segment consists of companies that produce iron and steel products from their own mills. These products include fat-rolled sheets, tin plates, pipes, tubes, and products made of stainless steel, titanium, and high alloy steels. Iron and steel foundries, which cast various products, typically purchase iron and steel from other firms. The industry also includes metal service centres and other metal merchant wholesalers, which distribute, import, or export ferrous products. Steel production occurs via two primary methods: the Basic Oxygen Furnace (Bof), which uses iron ore as an input, and the Electric Arc Furnace (EAF), which uses scrap steel. Many companies in the industry operate on an international scale. Note: With a few exceptions, most companies do not mine their own ore to manufacture steel and iron products.

fields.name: Leisure Facilities
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Leisure Facilities are Energy Management; Product Quality & Safety; Employee Health & Safety.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, circularity & recycling, food waste and supply chain management from an environmental; customer welfare, modern slavery and labour rights from a social; and data privacy from a governance perspective. Circularity and recycling are key considerations for this sector, for example the recent material bans on straws and cutlery. There  is also a consumer and regulatory focus on hard to recycle and on the go consumption, e.g. coffee cups, lids and stirrers. Deposit return schemes (DRS) are being trialled globally which impact those who sell plastic bottles for on the go consumption and food waste is a key area of focus. Additionally, modern slavery prevalence and labour rights are material considerations.

Contamination Risk: Leisure Facilities operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Leisure Facilities industry is comprised of companies that operate entertainment, travel, and recreation facilities and services. Companies in this industry operate amusement parks, movie theatres, ski resorts, sports stadiums, and athletic clubs and other venues. Leisure facilities companies mainly generate revenue by providing live, digital, and/or interactive entertainment to millions of guests and customers annually across various locations.

fields.name: Managed Care
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Managed Care are Data Security; Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, recycled materials, energy management and waste management from an environmental; and working conditions from a social perspective. Consumables and the use of recycled items and volume of disposable items are important to consider here. GHG emissions poses a risk from high energy use in large settings, such as hospitals. Work conditions is of key importance when considering fair pay, zero-hour contracts and worker’s rights, especially for support staff such as cleaners. There is also a high potential of modern slavery within this sector. SASB recognises customer welfare as important, which relates to client/ patient care, including ethics and safeguarding, particularly vulnerable patients.

Contamination Risk: Managed Care operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Managed Care industry offers health insurance products for individual, commercial, Medicare, and Medicaid members. Companies also provide administrative services and network access for self-funded insurance plans and manage pharmacy benefits. Enrolment in managed care has traditionally been correlated with employment rates, while revenues are driven by the inflation of medical costs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act reduced the percentage of uninsured adults, and created additional demand for the industry’s plans. However, legislative uncertainty and a focus on reducing health care costs may create downward pricing pressure and continue to drive consolidation within the industry. In addition, a focus on patient outcomes and plan performance continue to shape the industry’s sustainability risks and opportunities

fields.name: Marine Ports
fields.description:
Marine Ports is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to fuel management, hazardous materials, waste management and the physical impacts of climate change from an environmental, and modern slavery, trafficking, health & safety and labour rights from a social perspective. Hazardous materials pose as a key risk in terms of associated spills from fuel use and management of vessel waste, especially in the context of international regulations such as The International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL). There is the potential for significant risks associated with modern slavery and labour rights, especially considering the prevalence of migrant workers. The physical impacts of climate change are likely to have a significant impact, for example sea level rise affecting ports and increasing frequency of extreme weather such as storms. 

Contamination Risk: Marine Ports operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Marine infrastructure includes the platforms, subsea structures, pipelines and cables crucial to offshore activities in areas such as oil and gas, energy and telecom. It also includes the base for port operations to serve vessel, cargo and passengers which pass through ports. The development of port infrastructures requires capital-intensive investments, a long lead-time and therefore long-term planning. This means that the design of port infrastructures anticipates the needs of the logistics and transport sector. Port infrastructures also anticipates and adapt to the development of new waterborne activities (blue growth) and to other external factors, such as new extreme weather conditions resulting from climate change.

fields.name: Marine Transportation
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Marine Transportation are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Ecological Impacts; Employee Health & Safety; Business Ethics; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management, hazardous materials, waste management and the physical impacts of climate change from an environmental; and modern slavery, trafficking and labour rights from a social perspective. Hazardous materials are a key risk in terms of potential spills from fuel use and management of vessel waste should be a consideration, especially in the context of international regulations such as MARPOL (The International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships). There is the potential for significant risks associated with modern slavery and labour rights, especially considering the prevalence of migrant workers. The physical impacts of climate change are likely to have a significant impact, for example sea level rise affecting ports and increasing frequency of extreme weather such as storms.

Contamination Risk: Marine Transportation operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Marine Transportation industry consists of companies that provide deep-sea, coastal, and/or river-way freight shipping services. It is of strategic importance to international trade and its revenues are tied to macroeconomic cycles. Key activities include transportation of containerised and bulk freight, including consumer goods and a wide range of commodities, and transportation of chemicals and petroleum products in tankers. Due to the global scope of the industry, companies operate in many countries and under diverse legal and regulatory frameworks.

fields.name: Meat, Poultry and Dairy
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Meat, Poultry & Dairy are GHG Emissions, Energy Management, Water & Wastewater Management; Ecological Impacts; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also point to the application of Genetic Modification (GM), climate change, animal welfare and food waste from an environmental; and worker's rights and fair pay from a social perspective. GM feed and supplements poses a risk, with regards to the banning of hormone injections in some regions. Animal welfare standards merits consideration during raising, transport and at abattoir. Management of food waste is important, particularly for considering substandard products being acceptable and the wastage to animal food. Packaging is a key consideration, with a focus on the use of single-use plastics (SUP) and non-recyclable packaging within the industry. Worker's rights is an area of importance, especially the risk of forced/ child labour and poor working conditions, as well as ensuring the fair payment of suppliers.

Contamination Risk: Meat, Poultry & Dairy operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Meat, Poultry & Dairy industry produces raw and processed animal products, including meats, eggs, and dairy products, for human and animal consumption. Key activities include animal raising, slaughtering, processing, and packaging. The industry’s largest companies have international operations, and companies are vertically integrated to varying degrees, depending on the type of animal produced. Large industry operators typically rely on contract or independent farmers to supply their animals, and may have varying degrees of control over their operations. The industry sells products primarily to the Processed Foods industry and to retail distributors that distribute finished products to key end markets including restaurants, livestock and pet feed consumers, and grocery retailers.

fields.name: Media Production & Distribution
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Media & Entertainment are Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Competitive Behaviour.

RiskHorizon would also then point to access and affordability from a social perspective. In terms of customer welfare, this is most relevant to content and ensuring protection of minors from unsuitable materials including pornography, gambling and advertising. From a environmental perspective, particularly for larger firms, energy use and therefore Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions can be of concern. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving). Diversity and inclusion can also be a topic of concern.

Contamination Risk: Media & Entertainment operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Media and entertainment companies create content and/or acquire rights to distribute content over cable or broadcast media, including entertainment programs, news, music, and children’s programming. Companies in this industry also publish books, newspapers, and periodicals, and broadcast radio and local television programming. Note: Companies in the Media & Entertainment industry are increasingly engaged in distributing content via the Internet. The SASB standards for such activities are outlined in the Internet Media & Services industry standard. For the purposes of this standard, it is assumed that media and entertainment companies distribute content using traditional channels, such as television broadcasts and movie theater screenings. Therefore, issues such as data center energy use and online privacy, which may be material for companies that deliver content online, are not covered by this industry standard.

fields.name: Medical Equipment
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Medical Equipment & Supplies are Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Business Ethics. 

RiskHorizon would also then point to material sourcing, waste, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management and packaging from an environmental; and working conditions and fair pay from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. The environmental impact associated with conflict minerals, such as metals is important. GHG emissions and energy use pose as risks during production and distribution. Prioritising revenue savings programmes associated with better waste segregation from clinical to recycling is significant, also considering compliance and reporting requirements for hazardous waste streams. Product packaging, including recycled content, recyclability and refillable capabilities merits consideration, including finished products and the transit packaging. Fair pay and worker’s rights is important to consider, as well as fair pricing and contracts. Cyber security is significant to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Medical Equipment & Supplies operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Medical Equipment & Supplies industry researches, develops, and produces medical, surgical, dental, ophthalmic, and veterinary instruments and devices. Products are used in settings, including hospitals, clinics, and laboratories, and range from disposable items to highly specialised equipment. The increased prevalence of diseases associated with unhealthy lifestyles and an ageing population are important factors that may impact growth in this industry. Emerging markets and the expansion of health insurance in the U.S. will contribute to further growth. However, the extension of government insurance programs, provider and payer consolidation, and regulatory emphasis on reduced costs in all markets may result in downward pricing pressure.

fields.name: Metals & Mining
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Metals & Mining are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water and Wastewater Management; Waste and Hazardous Materials Management; Ecological Impacts; Human Rights & Community Relations; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to ecological impacts such as habitat loss and water stress from an environmental perspective, community relations and human rights (often interlinked) and labour rights from a social perspective and corruption from governance a governance perspective. SASB considers the risk of child labour to be low, however RiskHorizon would caution that this could be of concern in developing countries or within such companies’ supply chains. Supply chain risk across all issues of concern should be considered to be a higher concern for metals businesses, especially where this supply chains extend into developing countries. Additional scrutiny will be required if the business uses any conflict minerals such as gold, tantalum, tin, tungsten.

Contamination Risk: Metals & Mining operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Metals & Mining industry is involved in extracting metals and minerals, producing ores, quarrying stones, smelting and manufacturing metals, refining metals, and providing mining support activities. It also produces iron ores, rare earth metals, and precious metals and stones. Larger companies in this industry are vertically integrated - from mining across global operations to wholesaling metals to customers.

fields.name: Mixed Support Services
fields.description:
Mixed Support Services is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions (including Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), hazardous materials and environmental compliance from an environmental, and labour practices including modern slavery prevalence, worker health & safety and staff development and retention, from a social perspective. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving).

Contamination Risk: Mixed Support Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Mixed Support Services includes cleaning, catering, maintenance, storage and warehousing, uniform rental and laundry services. The cleaning service industry includes a wide range of services required by commercial and residential sectors. It comprises maid services, window cleaning, floor cleaning, carpet & upholstery cleaning and various other cleaning services, which are used by residential and commercial consumers. These services have gained popularity, owing to factors such as growth in construction activities, investment in real estate, increased disposable income and growth in number of working women, which have led to progressive cleaning services market trends.

fields.name: Mortgage Finance
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Mortgage Finance are Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fair pricing, access and employee engagement from a social, and transparency and compliance and cyber security, from a governance perspective. The industry receives significant scrutiny around the transparency of information given to clients/customers in order for them to make informed decisions. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Mortgage Finance operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Mortgage Finance industry provides an essential public good in enabling consumers to purchase homes, and contributes to the overall home ownership rate. Companies in the industry lend capital to individual and commercial customers with property as collateral. The primary products are residential and commercial mortgages, while other services offered include: mortgage servicing, title insurance, closing and settlement services, and valuation. In addition, mortgage finance firms own, manage, and finance real estate related investments such as mortgage pass-through certificates and collateralised mortgage obligations. Recent trends in the regulatory environment indicate a significant shift toward consumer protection, disclosure, and accountability. Legislation passed in response to the 2008 mortgage crisis demonstrates the potential for further alignment between the interests of society and those of long-term investors.

fields.name: Multiline & Speciality Retailers
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Multiline and Speciality Retailers & Distributors are Energy Management; Data Security; Labour Practices; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Product Design & Lifecycle Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to ethical trading and materials sourcing from an environmental and social perspective. The increased use of recycled materials, pollution, product design, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and energy management are important from an environmental, and health & safety from a social perspective. Materials sourcing and supply chain management is especially important for conflict minerals, metals and regulated chemicals, e.g. phthalates in children's toys. Product design is identified by SASB; "built to last" designs, and consideration of repairability and the ease of recycling is becoming increasingly important. Consideration of physical stores and risks of flooding, accessibility, asbestos and shop fitting (e.g. recycled materials used in partitioning's) as well as staff pay and conditions, and the prevalence of temporary contracts and zero hours contracts, for example.

Contamination Risk: Multiline and Speciality Retailers & Distributors operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Multiline and Specialty Retailers & Distributors industry encompasses a variety of retailing categories such as department stores, mass merchants, home products stores, and warehouse clubs, as well as a smaller segment of distributors like electronics wholesalers and automotive wholesalers. Common to these companies (except for the distribution segment) is that they manage global supply chains to anticipate consumer demands, keep costs low, and keep products stocked in their brick-and-mortar storefronts. This is a highly competitive industry, in which each company category generally has a small number of key players, characterised by generally low margins. The relatively substitutable nature of retail makes companies in this industry especially susceptible to reputational risks.

fields.name: Non-alcoholic Beverages
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Non-Alcoholic Beverages are GHG Emissions; Energy Management, Water & Wastewater Management; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, packaging and waste from an environmental perspective and health & safety and consumer protection from a social perspective. Product packaging is a key consideration, for example the use of recycled glass for bottling and aluminium for canning and end of life recyclability and associated labelling for consumers is critical. Other trends are towards lightweight glass, removing plastic (e.g. can rings) and inclusion of PCR in secondary packaging. Health & safety at production and bottling plants and throughout the supply chain merits consideration. 

Contamination Risk: Non-Alcoholic Beverages operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Non-Alcoholic Beverages industry produces a broad range of beverage products, including various carbonated soft drinks, syrup concentrates, juices, energy and sport drinks, teas, coffee, and water products. The industry is dominated by large, international companies. Companies partake in syrup manufacturing, marketing, bottling operations, and distribution, with larger companies typically being more vertically integrated into operations that bottle, sell, and distribute the finished products.

fields.name: Oil & Gas Exploration & Production
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Oil & Gas Exploration & Production are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Ecological Impacts; Human Rights & Community Relations; Employee Health & Safety; Business Model Resilience; Business Ethics; Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to transition risk from an environmental, labour conditions from a social, and bribery and corruption from a governance perspective. SASB identifies the importance of hazardous materials, which relates to spills during extraction, storage and movement which also have the potential for ecological impacts. From a transition perspective, as global governments and businesses transition to a zero carbon future, demand for oil is likely to decrease. Human rights and community relations risks include the potential for impacts to indigenous communities.

Contamination Risk: Oil & Gas Exploration & Production operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Oil & Gas - Exploration & Production (E&P) companies explore for, extract, or produce energy products such as crude oil and natural gas, which comprise the upstream operations of the oil and gas value chain. Companies in the industry develop conventional and unconventional oil and gas reserves; these include, but are not limited to, shale oil and/or gas reserves, oil sands, and gas hydrates. Activities covered by this standard include the development of both on-shore and off-shore reserves. The E&P industry creates contracts with the Oil and Gas Services industry to conduct several E&P activities and to obtain equipment and oilfield services.

fields.name: Oil & Gas Midstream
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Oil & Gas Midstream are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Ecological Impacts; Competitive Behaviour; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to hazardous materials and transition risk from an environmental, labour conditions, human rights, health & safety and community relations from a social, and bribery and corruption from a governance perspective. Hazardous materials are of importance due to the risks related to spills during refining, storage and movement which also have the potential for ecological impacts. From a transition perspective, as global governments and businesses transition to a zero carbon future, demand for oil is likely to decrease. Labour conditions poser a risk in terms of modern slavery and the treatment of workers. Additionally, human rights and community relations risks include the potential for impacts to indigenous communities.

Contamination Risk: Oil & Gas Midstream operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Oil and Gas - Midstream industry consists of companies involved in the transportation or storage of natural gas, crude oil, and refined petroleum products. Midstream natural gas activities involve gathering, transport, and processing of natural gas from the wellhead, as well as the removal of impurities, production of natural gas liquids, storage, pipeline transport, and shipping, liquefaction, or re-gasification of liquefied natural gas. Midstream oil activities mainly involve transport of crude oil and refined products over land, using a network of pipes and pumping stations, as well as trucks and rail cars, and over seas and rivers via tanker ships or barges. Companies that operate bulk stations and terminals, as well as those that manufacture and install storage tanks and pipelines, are also part of this industry.

fields.name: Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Competitive Behaviour; Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to biodiversity, fuel management and transition risk from an environmental, labour conditions, human rights and community relations from a social, and bribery and corruption from a governance perspective. Hazardous materials are of importance due to the risks related to spills during refining, storage and movement which also have the potential for ecological impacts. From a transition perspective, as global governments and businesses transition to a zero carbon future, demand for oil is likely to decrease. Labour conditions poser a risk in terms of modern slavery and the treatment of workers. Additionally, human rights and community relations risks include the potential for impacts to indigenous communities.

Contamination Risk: Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Oil & Gas - Refining & Marketing (R&M) companies refine petroleum products, market oil and gas products, and/ or operate gas stations and convenience stores, all of which comprise the downstream operations of the oil and gas value chain. The types of refinery products and crude oil inputs influence the complexity of the refining process used, with different expenditure needs and intensity of environmental and social impacts.

fields.name: Oil & Gas Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Oil & Gas Services are GHG Emissions; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Ecological Impacts; Employee Health & Safety; Business Ethics; Management of the Legal & Regulatory Environment; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to air quality, fuel management and transition risk from an environmental, labour conditions and community relations from a social, and  bribery and corruption from a governance perspective. Ecological impacts, waste and wastewater are identified by SASB with the most significant risks associated with spills and leaks during surveying and drilling. From a transition perspective, as global governments and businesses transition to a zero carbon future, demand for oil is likely to decrease. SASB also identifies employee health & safety which also extends to wellbeing, especially for employees working in remote locations.

Contamination Risk: Oil & Gas Services operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Oil and gas services companies provide support services, manufacture equipment, or are contract drillers for oil and natural gas exploration and production (E&P) companies. The drilling and drilling-support segment comprises companies that drill for oil and natural gas on-shore and off-shore on a contract basis. Companies in this segment may also manufacture jack-up rigs, semisubmersible rigs, and drill ships. Companies in the oilfield services segment manufacture equipment that is used in the extraction, storage, and transportation of oil and natural gas. They also provide support services such as seismic surveying, equipment rental, well cementing, and well monitoring. These services are commonly provided on a contractual basis, and the customer will purchase or lease the materials and equipment from the service provider. Service companies may also provide personnel or subject matter expertise as part of their scope of service. The contractual relationship between oil and gas services companies and their customers plays a significant role in determining the material impacts of their sustainability performance. Besides the rates charged, companies compete on the basis of their operational and safety performance, technology and process offerings, and reputation.

fields.name: Pharmaceuticals
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals are Human Rights & Community Relations; Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Supply Chain Management; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the use of chemicals, packaging, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and energy management from an environmental; and fair pay, working conditions, animal testing and ethical trading from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. 
The use of harmful/banned chemicals and biological inputs (e.g. micro-organisms), poses a risk for contaminating land. Animal testing and the conditions for human trials is another significant consideration. Product packaging including recycled content merits consideration for both the finished product and transit packaging (e.g. reusable crates). GHG emissions and energy use are likely to have impacts during production and distribution within this industry. Fair pay and working conditions are important considerations in relation to modern slavery prevalence. Cyber and data security is important to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Biotechnology & Pharmaceuticals industry develops, manufactures, and markets a range of brand-name and generic medications. A signifcant portion of the industry is driven by research and development, a high risk of product failure during clinical trials, and the need to obtain regulatory approval. Concerns over pricing practices and consolidation within the sector have created downward pricing pressures. Demand for the industry’s products is largely driving by population demographics, rates of insurance coverage, disease profles, and economic conditions.

fields.name: Processed Foods
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Processed Foods are Energy Management; Water and Wastewater Management; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Supply Chain Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to the application of Genetic Modification (GM) and chemicals, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, climate change, packaging and biodiversity from an environmental; and fair contracts, worker's rights, health & safety and consumer protection from a social perspective. Understanding climate change impacts (e.g. flooding) and biodiversity are important for loss of virgin forest and deforestation, including for cash crops such as soya. Packaging is key, including the use of recycled glass for bottling, aluminium for canning, end of life recyclability and consumer labels. Other trends are lightweight glass, removing plastic (e.g. can rings) and post-consumer resin (PCR) in secondary packaging. Worker’s rights and the risks of forced/child labour merits consideration. Additionally, fair contracts and payment of suppliers and health & safety during manufacturing and distribution are all important. 

Contamination Risk: Processed Foods operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Processed Foods industry includes companies that process and package foods such as bread, frozen foods, snack foods, pet foods, and condiments for retail consumer consumption. Typically, these products are made ready to consume, are marketed for retail consumers, and can be found on food retailers’ shelves. The industry is characterised by large and complex ingredient supply chains, as many companies source ingredients from around the world. Large companies operate globally, and international opportunities are driving growth.

fields.name: Professional Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Professional & Commercial Services are Data Security; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also point to selling practices and competitive behaviour from a governance perspective, both linked to transparency, organisational integrity and code of conduct. From a environmental perspective, particularly for larger firms, energy use and therefore Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions can be of concern. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving).

Contamination Risk: Professional & Commercial Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Professional & Commercial Services industry includes companies that rely on the unique skills and knowledge of their employees to serve a range of clients. Services are often provided on an assignment basis, where an individual or team is responsible for the delivery of services to clients. offerings include, but are not limited to, management and administration consulting services, such as staffing and executive search services; legal, accounting, and tax preparation services; and financial and non-financial information services. Non-financial information service providers may specialise in an array of topics such as energy, healthcare, real estate, technology, and science. Financial information service companies include credit and rating agencies as well as data and portfolio analytics providers. Customers of professional and commercial service providers include private and public for-profit institutions and non-profit organisations.

fields.name: Pulp and Paper Products
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Pulp & Paper Products are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to pollution, energy management and sustainable sourcing from an environmental; and health and safety and employee engagement from a social perspective. Pollution and energy management are likely to have significant environmental impacts during the production phases. Sustainable sourcing poses a risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and the associated land use and environmental impacts, as well as consideration of climate risk factors around the supply chain. Product design considerations particularly using recycled sources and recyclability are important. Employee health & safety will also be critical, as is employee engagement for ensuring staff development and wellbeing. 

Contamination Risk: Pulp & Paper Products operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Pulp & Paper Products industry consists of companies that manufacture a range of wood pulp and paper products, including pulp fibre, paper packaging and sanitary paper, office paper, newsprint, and paper for industrial applications. Companies in the industry typically function as business-to-business entities and may have operations in multiple countries, such as the U.S., Canada, and Brazil . While some integrated companies own or manage timber tracts and are engaged in forest management, sustainability issues arising from these activities are addressed in SASB’s Forestry Management (RR-FM) industry standard.

fields.name: Rail Transportation
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Rail Transportation are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Employee Health & Safety; Competitive Behaviour; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management, hazardous materials and the physical impacts of climate change from an environmental, and trafficking from a social perspective.  Hazardous materials are a key risk in terms of potential spills from fuel use. The physical impacts of climate change should also be considered due to the potential for flooding and extreme weather to impact infrastructure. Furthermore, transition risks in terms of rising fossil fuel prices and carbon pricing will likely impact the industry albeit balanced by increased demand with the transition of road and air transport to rail.

Contamination Risk: Rail Transportation operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Rail Transportation industry consists of companies that provide rail freight shipping and support services. Key activities include shipping containerised and bulk freight, including consumer goods and commodities. Rail companies typically own, maintain, and operate their rail networks, which may require significant capital expenditures. The U.S. operates the longest railroad network in the world, followed closely by Russia, China, India, Canada, Germany, and France. The industry exhibits economies of density due to its network effects, lending itself to natural monopoly conditions. Together with the large sunk costs of rail infrastructure, this provides a competitive advantage to incumbent firms in the industry and creates barriers to entry for new firms. Note: The scope of the Rail Transportation industry does not include passenger rail transportation.

fields.name: Real Estate
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Real Estate are Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to material sourcing, recycled materials, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and climate change from an environmental; and health & safety, working conditions and fair pricing from a social perspective. Recycled materials, including virgin compared to recycled materials (e.g. certified timber) is important and the durability of build "built to last" and the repairability, disposable and easily recyclable capabilities. GHG emissions are important during production, distribution and embedded carbon. Consideration of climate change risks (e.g. flooding), in the siting and design. Other build design factors, including accessibility, energy, recyclability and use of natural light are important. Health & safety is important, including sub-contractor and end-user safety and working conditions, with potential risk of forced/child labour, particularly with sub-contractors. Cyber security is also important to minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Real Estate operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Real Estate industry is composed of companies that own, develop, and generally operate income-producing real estate assets. Companies in this industry are commonly structured as real estate investment trusts (REITs) and operate in a wide range of segments within the real estate industry, including residential, retail, office, health care, industrial, and hotel properties. REITs typically focus on the direct ownership of real estate assets, thereby providing investors with the opportunity to obtain real estate exposure without direct asset ownership and management. Although REITs are often concentrated in one segment of the Real Estate industry, many REITs are diversified through investment in multiple property types.

fields.name: Real Estate Services
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Real Estate Services are Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Business Ethics.

RiskHorizon would also then point to health safety, employee engagement and fair pricing from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. Employee and end-user health & safety and welfare is an important factor to consider, as well as employee development and engagement. Fair pricing and contracts are important within this sector, as well as anti-bribery and corruption. Cyber security and data is a significant area to ensure safety of systems and minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Real Estate Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Real Estate Services industry is composed of companies that provide a range of services to real estate owners, tenants, investors, and developers. Primary services include property management, brokerage, appraisal, and information services for real estate owners. Property management services may include leasing, tenant relations, building maintenance, and building security. Many companies also provide brokerage services, facilitating sales and leasing transactions. Appraisals and other advisory or information services are other specialised services that are commonly provided to clients. Companies in the industry play important roles in the real estate value chain, which is a substantial part of the global economy.

fields.name: Restaurants
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Restaurants are Energy Management; Water and Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Product Quality & Safety; Customer Welfare; Labour Practices; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also point to packaging and food waste from an environmental; and fair pay and health and safety from a social perspective. 
Product packaging is key, especially for takeaway food and including recycled content, reducing single-use plastic (SUP) and consumer messaging for disposal. The material bans on straws and cutlery also merits consideration and focusing on hard to recycle and on the go consumption (e.g. coffee cups), which is expected to roll out and include materials, such as sandwich packs. There is also an increasing number of Deposit Return Schemes (DRS) globally which will impact those who sell plastic bottles for on the go consumption. Health & safety is also important, including working conditions such as fair pay (including suppliers), working hours and the prevalence of zero hours contracts.

Contamination Risk: Restaurants operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in the Restaurants industry prepare meals, snacks, and beverages to customers’ orders for immediate on- and off-premises consumption. Broadly divided into three sub-categories, the restaurant industry includes limited-service eating places, casual full-service eating places, and upscale full-service eating places. Limited-service restaurants provide services to customers who order and pay before eating. Fast-food restaurants represent the largest share of the limited-service restaurants segment. Full-service restaurants offer more service, food for consumption primarily on-premise, and typically reflect higher quality food and prices.

fields.name: Road Transportation
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Road Transportation are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Employee Health & Safety; Critical Incident Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to fuel management, hazardous materials and the physical impacts of climate change from an environmental, and trafficking from a social perspective. Hazardous materials are a key risk in terms of potential spills from fuel use. The physical impacts of climate change should also be considered due to the potential for flooding and extreme weather to impact infrastructure. Furthermore, transition risks in terms of rising fossil fuel prices and carbon pricing will likely impact the industry.

Contamination Risk: Road Transportation operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Road Transportation industry consists of companies that provide long- and short-haul freight trucking services. Key activities include the shipment of containerised and bulk freight, including consumer goods and a wide variety of commodities. The industry is commonly broken down into two categories: truckload (vehicles carrying the goods of only one customer) and less-than-truckload (vehicles carrying the goods of multiple customers). Owner-operators comprise the vast majority of the industry due to the relative ease of entry, while a few large operators maintain market share through contracts with major shippers. Large companies often subcontract with owner-operators to supplement their owned feet.

fields.name: Security Commodity Exchanges
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Security Commodity Exchanges are Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Business Ethics; Systemic Risk Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to circularity from an environmental, fair pricing and accessibility from a social, and transparency, compliance and cyber security from a governance perspective. Secondary commodities trading and pricing, specifically plastic relative to oil prices are of particular relevance, as well as packaging Recovery Notes (PRN) and other certification trading prices which rely on demand and supply. Employee engagement, which also encompasses staff development, training and wellbeing is a key focus and furthermore, the sector has struggled historically to address diversity & inclusion, especially within senior and analytical roles. Cyber and data security is growing in importance, with substantial reputational and regulatory risks.

Contamination Risk: Security Commodity Exchanges operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Security and commodity exchanges operate marketplaces in the form of physical trading floors or electronic platforms for trading financial securities, commodities, or other financial instruments. Companies in the industry primarily generate revenue from fees on trades and for clearing transactions as well as listing fees. Competition for fees continues to increase with the advent of alternative trading platforms that offer less expensive trades and provide listing services. Recent trends in the regulatory environment suggest a greater focus on transparency, risk management, and market stability. As new policies and market transformations encourage more responsible management of social capital and strong governance, forms that can address all forms of capital—not just financial—will be better positioned to protect shareholder value in the future.

fields.name: Semiconductors
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Semiconductors are GHG Emissions; Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Employee Health & Safety; Employee Engagement, Diversity & Inclusion; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency; Competitive Behaviour.

RiskHorizon would also then point to environmental compliance and climate change from an environmental; supply chain management from an environmental and social; and labour rights from a social perspective. SASB identifies waste management as a key risk, which is important for considering end of life and circularity of products and services. Other manufacturing impacts include the risks involved in using hazardous materials, wastewater generation and treatment, energy and water use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions. Environmental compliance and management is critical, due to the high potential for impact and usually strict regulatory focus on the sector, including through environmental permitting and licensing. Consideration of climate change risks - flooding and other extreme weather events in the location, distribution network and supply chain. There is also a sustainable sourcing risk, particularly around the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of enforced and child labour. 

Contamination Risk: Semiconductors operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
