fields.short_description: The Semiconductors industry includes companies that design or manufacture semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, their raw materials and components, or capital equipment. Some companies in the industry provide outsourced manufacturing, assembly, or other services for designers of semiconductor devices.

fields.name: Software & IT Services
fields.description:
Software & IT Services is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to energy use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions (resulting predominantly from datacentres) from an environmental; staff training and development and customer welfare from a social; and data privacy and cyber security from a governance perspective. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving). Diversity and inclusion issues, together with staff retention may require attention.

Contamination Risk: Software & IT Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.

fields.name: Solar Energy
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Solar Technology & Project Developers are Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Ecological Impacts; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, pollution, sustainable sourcing, biodiversity and climate change from an environmental; and child labour, community engagement, product safety, health & safety, employee engagement and fair pricing from a social perspective. Sustainable sourcing poses a risk, particularly the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and the risk of forced/ child labour. Impacts of climate change (e.g. flooding) and biodiversity are important for building installations. Community engagement is vital for changes in land use. Product safety and design are important for minimising virgin material use and increasing recyclability and productivity. Health & safety is another area for consideration, as well as employee engagement. Fair pricing, contracts and anti-bribery and corruption practices would be a consideration of suppliers to large or single clients.

Contamination Risk: Solar Technology & Project Developers operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Solar Technology & Project Developers industry comprises companies that manufacture solar energy equipment, including solar photovoltaic (PV) modules, poly-silicon feedstock, solar thermal electricity-generation systems, solar inverters, and other related components. Companies may also develop, build, and manage solar energy projects and offer financing or maintenance services to customers. Two primary technologies are utilised in the industry: PV and concentrated solar power (CSP). Within solar PV, there are two main technologies: crystalline silicon-based solar and thin-film solar, which includes panels made using copper indium gallium selenide and cadmium telluride. The primary markets for solar panels are residential, non-residential (commercial and industrial), and utility-scale projects. Companies in the industry operate globally.

fields.name: Telecommunications
fields.description:
Telecommunications is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to energy use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions (particularly from datacentres) from an environmental; staff training and development and customer welfare from a social; and data privacy and cyber security from a governance perspective. Other considerations include the consumption of resources and especially non-renewable materials and physical environmental damage associated with core cabling and telephone line installation processes.

Contamination Risk: Telecommunications operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Telecommunications industry is made up of companies that make communication possible on a global scale, whether it is through the phone, internet, airwave cables, wires or wirelessly. These companies have created the infrastructure that allows data in words, voice, audio or video to be sent anywhere in the world. The largest companies in the sector are telephone (both wired and wireless), operators, satellite companies, cable companies and internet service providers. The sector is split into three basic sub-sectors: telecom equipment, telecom services and wireless communication. Telecom is growing less about voice and increasingly about video, text and data. Analysts foresee that product innovation and an increase in mergers and acquisitions will facilitate the continued growth and success of the industry. The continuing advances in high-speed mobile services and internet connectivity between devices keep driving innovation and competition within the sector.

fields.name: Tobacco
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Tobacco are Customer Welfare; Selling Practices & Product Labelling.

RiskHorizon would also then point to water use, the application of Genetic Modification (GM) and chemicals, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, climate change, packaging and biodiversity from an environmental; and fair contracts, worker's rights and health & safety from a social perspective. Understanding climate change impacts is important, including crop growth, yield, water demand and availability and flooding. Biodiversity impacts are also important in the context of loss of virgin forest and deforestation, including for cash crops such as soya and palm oil. GHG emissions poses a risk due to high energy users. Product packaging merits consideration for recyclability and consumer messaging for disposal. Worker's rights and the risks of forced/child labour is important, as well as fair contracts and payment of suppliers and health & safety during manufacturing and distribution.

Contamination Risk: Tobacco operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Tobacco industry is comprised of companies that manufacture tobacco products including cigarettes, cigars, and smokeless tobacco products. Many large tobacco companies operate globally. Companies may obtain or sell exclusive rights to sell certain brands of cigarettes in diverse markets. Most tobacco is grown by independent tobacco farmers, who typically sell their crops to tobacco merchants or to manufacturers under contract.

fields.name: Toys & Sporting Goods
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Toys & Sporting Goods are Product Quality & Safety; Supply Chain Management.

RiskHorizon would also then point to ethical trading and materials sourcing from an environmental and social perspective. The increased use of recycled materials, pollution, product design, Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and energy management are important from an environmental, and working conditions, fair pay and health & safety, from a social perspective. Materials sourcing and supply chain management is especially important for conflict minerals, metals and regulated chemicals, e.g. phthalates in children's toys.
"Built to last" designs, and consideration of repairability and the ease of recycling is becoming increasingly important.

Contamination Risk: Toys & Sporting Goods operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Toys & Sporting Goods industry comprises two distinct segments that produce leisure products: companies that manufacture toys and games, and companies that manufacture sporting and athletic goods, such as bicycles, golf clubs, fitness equipment, and other similar products. Companies in this industry primarily sell their products to consumers through retail stores. The level of manufacturing integration varies among and within segments of the industry; manufacturing is based primarily in Asia, with China accounting for a majority of production.

fields.name: Waste Management
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Waste Management are GHG Emissions; Air Quality; Waste & Hazardous Materials Management; Labour Practices; Employee Health & Safety; Business Model Resilience.

RiskHorizon would also then point to biodiversity, climate change and recycling facilities from an environmental; and worker rights, employee engagement and fair pricing from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. The restoration of landfill sites, including reintroducing biodiversity and community open space is important to consider. The physical impacts of climate change are likely to have significant impacts on facilities, therefore, innovation and increased capacity for recycling facilities are significant areas to consider. Employee welfare and rights is important, as well as employee engagement to ensure staff development and wellbeing. Fair pricing and contracts merit recognition within this sector, as well as anti-bribery and corruption. Cyber security and data is also important to ensure safety of systems and minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Waste Management operations are considered to be of high risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Waste Management industry includes companies that collect, store, dispose of, recycle, or treat various forms of waste from residential, commercial, and industrial clients. Types of waste include municipal solid waste, hazardous waste, recyclable materials, and compostable or organic materials. Major companies are commonly vertically integrated, providing a range of services from waste collection to landfilling and recycling, while others provide specialised services such as treating medical and industrial wastes. Waste-to-energy operations are a distinct industry segment. Certain industry players also provide environmental engineering and consulting services, mostly to large industrial clients.

fields.name: Water Utilities
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Water Utilities & Services are Energy Management; Water & Wastewater Management; Access & Affordability; Product Quality & Safety; Business Model Resilience; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency; Physical Impacts of Climate Change.

RiskHorizon would also then point to biodiversity from an environmental; and health & safety, employee engagement, worker rights and fair pricing from a social; and cyber security from a governance perspective. Consideration of biodiversity and resource use, such as leisure use, for both the abstraction source and receiving waters (for wastewater) are important within this sector. Innovation for reduced water use, including leak detection in supply pipework and improvement in wastewater treatment are key elements for consideration. Employee health & safety is important, as well as employee welfare and rights, and employee engagement to ensure development and staff wellbeing. Fair pricing and contracts are important within this sector, as well as anti-bribery and corruption. Cyber security and data is also important to ensure safety of systems and minimise business risk.

Contamination Risk: Water Utilities & Services operations are considered to be of moderate risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: Companies in the Water Utilities & Services industry own and operate water supply and wastewater treatment systems (generally structured as regulated utility businesses), or provide operational and other specialised water services to system owners (usually market-based operations). Water supply systems include the sourcing, treatment, and distribution of water to residences, businesses, and other entities such as governments. Wastewater systems collect and treat wastewater, including sewage, grey water, industrial waste fluids, and stormwater runoff, before discharging the resulting effluent back into the environment. Note: The scope of the Water Utilities & Services industry (IF-WU) excludes water services that fall into the category of infrastructure design and development. These activities fall within the Engineering & Construction Services industry (IF-EC).

fields.name: Wind Energy
fields.description:
SASB states that the most material issues associated with Wind Technology & Project Developers are Employee Health & Safety; Product Design & Lifecycle Management; Materials Sourcing & Efficiency.

RiskHorizon would also then point to Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, energy management, waste management, pollution, sustainable sourcing, biodiversity and climate change from an environmental; and child labour, transparency, community engagement, product safety, health & safety, employee engagement and fair pricing from a social perspective. Impacts of production, particularly from metals and process chemicals poses environmental challenges. Also, sourcing risks, particularly the use of virgin materials and conflict minerals and potential forced/ child labour. Impacts of climate change (e.g. flooding) and biodiversity are important for building installations. Community engagement is vital for changes in land use.   Product safety and design are important for minimising virgin material use and increasing recyclability and productivity. Considerations of health & safety and fair pricing and contracts are important of suppliers to large or single clients.

Contamination Risk: Wind Technology & Project Developers operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The Wind Technology & Project Developers industry comprises companies that manufacture wind turbines, blades, towers, and other components of wind power systems. Companies that develop, build, and manage wind energy projects are also included within the scope of this industry. Manufacturers may also offer post-sale maintenance and support services. Turbines can be installed onshore or offshore, which can cause differences in wind-generating capacity and create challenges in project development for each type of installation. Most major wind technology companies operate globally.

fields.name: Security Services
fields.description:
Security Services is not currently a SASB industry category.

RiskHorizon would point to fuel use and Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from an environmental, and staff and client safety and wellbeing from a social perspective. There are specific issues associated with bribery and corruption and the employment rights and contractual arrangements of staff from a social perspective. Health and safety issues should consider both office based ergonomics issues, staff wellbeing and mental health issues, and staff travel (especially driving).

Contamination Risk: Security Services operations are considered to be of low risk from a soil and groundwater contamination perspective. Historical land use and ancillary operations should also be considered.
fields.short_description: The security services industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in providing guard and patrol services, armoured car services including picking up and the delivery of money, receipts or other valuable items with personnel and equipment to protect such properties while in transit and security system services. Increasing urbanisation, rapid economic development and consequent asset creation are drivers of growth for the industry. High growth in sectors such as retailing and real estate are adding impetus to growth.
